description: Unitary folding (also called gate folding or circuit folding) is the most widely used noise scaling technique for Zero-Noise Extrapolation. It amplifies noise by inserting identity-equivalent gate sequences into the circuit.

The key insight is that for any unitary gate G, the sequence G G† G is mathematically equivalent to G alone, but executes three times as many gates. Since each gate application introduces noise, this effectively triples the noise level while preserving the ideal computation.
Folding can be applied globally (folding the entire circuit) or locally (folding individual gates). Local folding provides finer control over the noise amplification factor.
how_it_works: Start with the original circuit implementing unitary U.
To achieve noise scale factor λ, apply the transformation G → G(G†G)ⁿ where n = (λ-1)/2.
For global folding with λ = 3: the circuit U becomes U U† U. For λ = 5: U U† U U† U.
For local folding, apply the same transformation to individual gates.
Fractional scale factors can be achieved by folding only a subset of gates (partial folding).
Execute the folded circuits at multiple noise levels and extrapolate to the zero-noise limit.
advantages: Simple to implement using standard gate operations
Works on any gate-based quantum computer
Widely supported in software frameworks (Mitiq, Qiskit, Cirq, PennyLane)
disadvantages: Exact folding only achieves odd integer scale factors (1, 3, 5, ...)
For non-Hermitian gates, G and G† may have different noise profiles, causing non-linear scaling
May fail to amplify coherent errors (since G†G can cancel systematic errors)
Does not scale SPAM (state preparation and measurement) noise
Server-side compiler optimization may undo the folding
use_cases: Zero-Noise Extrapolation on near-term quantum hardware
Variational quantum algorithms (VQE, QAOA) where expectation values are measured
Situations where pulse-level control is unavailable
Quick prototyping of error mitigation strategies
